prompt:
Is the person who wrote this in the wrong in the following situation?

"""
AITA because I want my hair fixed, for free, by the hairdresser?
[What I showed her](http://imgur.com/KmuiLRL)


[What I got](http://imgur.com/gEiWAi4)


I asked my stylist to do a light brown rose gold, and emphasized that I wanted it a light brown, warm color.

I showed her the picture more than a week in advance of the appointment so she had time to get any colors she didn’t have. 

I told her multiple times I wanted a light brown.  I know you can’t perfectly match the picture, but I think I made it obvious I wanted more brown than red in my hair.  I would have been fine without the rose tint.  My hair was bleach blonde to begin with.

She’s going to try to fix it but I don’t think I should have to pay, this is clearly not what I asked for.  Am I the asshole?
"""

I think the author is in the wrong but curious what you think.
Is the author in the wrong? Answer A for Yes (the author is in the wrong) and B for No (the author is not in the wrong). Answer nothing else.

thinking.text:
Okay, let's see. The user is asking whether the person who wrote the story is in the wrong. The situation is about a hair coloring mishap.

First, the person went to a hairdresser and showed them a picture of a light brown rose gold color. They emphasized wanting a light brown, warm color and mentioned that they wanted more brown than red. They even brought the picture a week in advance so the stylist could prepare. The result was something that looks much redder, and now they're saying they don't want to pay for the correction.

Hmm, the key points here are communication and expectations. The writer made their request clear, showing the picture multiple times and specifying the color. The stylist didn't follow the instructions accurately. The result is not what was agreed upon. 

Hairdressers are professionals, right? So if they take the time to show them the picture and explain the color, and the stylist still ends up with a different color, maybe they're at fault. The writer isn't to blame for wanting their hair fixed properly. They shouldn't have to pay for a mistake that wasn't theirs. 

But wait, could there be any misunderstanding? Like maybe the hairdresser thought the picture was just an example and the client wanted a different variation? However, the client explicitly stated the desired outcome and the stylist had time to prepare. So it's more on the stylist's end to deliver as per the instructions.

So, the answer would be B (No, the author is not in the wrong) because the responsibility lies with the hairdresser to meet the client's clear instructions. The client had communicated their needs properly, and the mistake was on the stylist's part.
